Description: Industrial and chemical solid waste - includes mercury containing devices, computers and electronics, batteries, silica gel, and other chemical solid waste.
Notes:
| See `Princeton Environmental Health and Safety <https://ehs.princeton.edu/laboratory-research/chemical-safety/chemical-waste/chemical-waste-solids>`_ for the delineation of these industrial subcategories.
 | 
 | See Volume 5, Chapter 2, Table 2.5 in the `IPCC National Greenhouse Gas Inventories <https://www.ipcc-nggip.iges.or.jp/public/2019rf/index.html>`_ for the source of Industrial waste default paramters (other).
 | 
 | Note that dry matter content is assumed to be 1 - water content and DOC for dry waste is assumed to be the same as DOC for wet waste.

Description: Food and organic waste, excluding yard and garden waste
Other waste not mentioned in any other category, including sanitary napkins and diapers.

Notes: Assigned DOCf to less decompostable waste in IPCC FOD model.

| Note that, in sewage sludge, fossil carbon can usually be neglected (IPCC Guidelines for NGHG Inventories, 5.19). See Table 5.2 for defaults. The Total Carbon 
 | 
 | Sewage sludge is estimated as a product of wastewater treatment from aerobic treatment facilities and septic tanks.
 | 
 | Assigned DOCf to less decompostable waste in IPCC FOD model.
